disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H1: Hyperscalers are price setters, MSPs are price takers
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Long-term MSP-hyperscaler agreements guaranteeing partner credit levels
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Reviewed Stage 2.5 partner documentation, searched for disclosed partner agreements in public filings, examined industry reporting on MSP-hyperscaler contracts
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.5 explicitly states partner credits are 'non-disclosed' and 'controlled by AWS/Azure/Google' with zero disclosed long-term guarantees. No evidence of multi-year credit protection agreements in Rackspace public disclosures or industry reporting for any major MSP.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of long-term credit guarantees supports hypothesis that hyperscalers maintain unilateral pricing control. MSPs have no contractual protection against credit reductions.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H1: Hyperscalers are price setters, MSPs are price takers
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that MSPs successfully raise prices without customer churn
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined Stage 2.1 email pricing case study as natural experiment of MSP pricing power, reviewed Stage 2.4 customer switching behavior across segments
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE FOUND. Stage 2.1 documents email hosting 706% price increase triggering 'immediate churn' and 'wave of churn' with partners describing impact as 'devastating'. This is DIRECT EVIDENCE of zero pricing power in low-lock-in segment - MSP attempted price increase, market rejected it through customer exodus. Disconfirms any claim of MSP pricing power.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Email price increase failure is PROOF of price-taking behavior when customer lock-in absent. Strengthens hypothesis that MSPs lack pricing power.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H2: Value migrating from MSPs to hyperscaler-direct
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of MSP margin expansion or value capture increase over time
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Analyzed Stage 2.2 margin data, compared current Public Cloud 10.4% gross margin to historical industry benchmarks, examined MSP peer financial disclosures where available
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.2 shows Public Cloud 10.4% gross margin which is BELOW historical industry margins of 15-20% from prior decade, indicating margin COMPRESSION not expansion. No evidence of MSP value capture increasing - all evidence points to compression and commoditization.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of margin expansion supports hypothesis that value is migrating away from MSPs. Margin compression over decade-long period demonstrates structural value loss.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H2: Value migrating from MSPs to hyperscaler-direct
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of customer migration FROM hyperscaler-direct TO MSPs (reverse value flow)
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Reviewed Stage 2.1 bookings and revenue trends, examined Stage 2.4 customer acquisition and churn patterns, searched for evidence of 'repatriation' or 'reverse cloud migration' benefiting MSPs
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.1 shows 21% net revenue leakage (14% bookings - 7% revenue decline) indicating customers leaving faster than acquiring - NET OUTFLOW. No evidence of customer migration from hyperscaler-direct to MSPs. 'Reverse cloud migration' discussions in industry focus on public-to-private migration for cost reasons, not hyperscaler-direct-to-MSP migration for service reasons.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of reverse migration supports hypothesis of unidirectional value flow from MSPs to hyperscalers. Customer flow is OUT of MSP model, not into it.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H3: Pricing power exists only in high-lock-in segments
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that low-lock-in segments can sustain price increases
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined Stage 2.1 email price increase as test case for low-lock-in segment pricing power, reviewed Stage 2.4 Public Cloud and Mid-Market customer behavior
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE. Email segment (ZERO lock-in per Stage 2.4) attempted 706% price increase and experienced immediate customer exodus per Stage 2.1, proving ZERO pricing power. This is direct experimental evidence disconfirming any pricing power in low-lock-in segments - when lock-in absent, customers refuse price increases by switching.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Email price increase failure PROVES hypothesis - low-lock-in segments have zero pricing power. Customers vote with their feet when switching is frictionless.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H3: Pricing power exists only in high-lock-in segments
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that margins are uniform across segments regardless of lock-in
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Compared Stage 2.2 segment margins (Private Cloud 38.6% vs Public Cloud 10.4%), examined Stage 2.4 lock-in assessments by segment
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE. Private Cloud (VERY HIGH lock-in per Stage 2.4) has 38.6% gross margin vs Public Cloud (LOW lock-in per Stage 2.4) has 10.4% gross margin - 28 percentage point differential correlating perfectly with lock-in levels. Margins are NOT uniform - they vary proportionally with switching costs and lock-in strength.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Margin differential across segments PROVES hypothesis that lock-in determines pricing power. High lock-in = high margin, low lock-in = commodity margin.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H4: Margin compression is structural not cyclical
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of margin recovery or stabilization in recent periods
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Analyzed Stage 2.1 and Stage 2.2 recent financial trends, examined whether margin compression is moderating or accelerating
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.1 shows revenue declining 7% YoY with 21% net leakage indicating ACCELERATING not stabilizing pressure. Stage 2.5 VMware 200-300% price shock (2023-2024) is RECENT compression event, not historical. No evidence of margin recovery - all recent evidence shows continued or accelerating compression.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of recovery and evidence of acceleration supports structural hypothesis. If compression were cyclical, would expect periods of recovery - none observed.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H4: Margin compression is structural not cyclical
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that MSPs are successfully differentiating and expanding margins
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Searched for MSP differentiation strategies succeeding in market, examined whether any MSPs achieving premium pricing or margin expansion
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.2 Public Cloud 10.4% margin is commodity-level providing zero evidence of successful differentiation. Stage 2.1 revenue decline with brand ('Fanatical Support') shows differentiation attempts failing. No evidence of MSP margin expansion in industry data - all public MSPs show compression or exit (2U acquisition by Presidio, Rackspace revenue decline, others).
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of differentiation success supports structural hypothesis. If margin compression were fixable through strategy, some MSPs would be succeeding - none are.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H5: Rackspace role commoditizing from value-add to interchangeable reseller
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that Rackspace brand commands premium over competitors
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined Stage 2.2 margin data for evidence of premium pricing, reviewed Stage 2.1 revenue trends for brand protection against decline, analyzed Stage 2.4 churn patterns for brand loyalty
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. Stage 2.2 Public Cloud 10.4% gross margin provides zero evidence of premium pricing - this is commodity-level margin. Stage 2.1 revenue declining 7% YoY proves brand insufficient to prevent customer losses. Stage 2.4 shows 15-25% Mid-Market and 25-40% SMB annual churn demonstrating brand not creating loyalty in low-lock-in segments. No premium pricing, no revenue protection, no loyalty - ZERO evidence of brand value.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of brand premium supports commoditization hypothesis. Rackspace operating with commodity economics despite brand investment, proving brand differentiation has failed.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H5: Rackspace role commoditizing from value-add to interchangeable reseller
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that customers choose Rackspace for unique capabilities vs alternatives
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Reviewed Stage 2.4 customer retention drivers, examined whether customers stay for service differentiation vs switching costs
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE. Stage 2.4 explicitly observes 'retention is STRUCTURAL not earned through superior service' - customers stay due to switching costs (Large Enterprise technical/operational lock-in) not because of service quality or unique capabilities. Where switching costs low (SMB, Mid-Market), customers churn at 15-40% annually despite same 'Fanatical Support'. This PROVES customers do NOT value Rackspace-specific capabilities when alternatives are accessible.
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Customer retention driven by switching costs not service differentiation PROVES commoditization. Rackspace has become interchangeable where lock-in absent.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: GENERAL: Rackspace retains market power or competitive advantages
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of proprietary technology, unique partnerships, patents, or other defensible competitive advantages
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Reviewed Stage 1 and Stage 2 materials for evidence of proprietary assets, examined partner relationships for exclusivity or preferential terms, searched for Rackspace-specific capabilities unavailable to competitors
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: NOT FOUND. No proprietary technology identified - Rackspace uses commodity platforms (VMware, AWS/Azure/Google, standard tooling). No exclusive partnerships - hyperscaler partnerships are non-exclusive standard partner programs per Stage 2.5. No patents or IP creating barriers. Only 'advantage' is customer switching costs in high-lock-in segments (operational lock-in not defensible competitive advantage - erodes over time as customers modernize and migrate).
disconfirming_evidence_searched.implication: Absence of defensible advantages supports conclusion that Rackspace operates in commodity market with no structural protections against commoditization or competitive pressure.
